Unfortunately, alcohol won't help you in the cold.  It causes blood to rush to the skin and makes you feel flushed, but this is the opposite of what the body needs, which is to keep the warmth near the most vital organs--the heart and brain.  Alcohol might make you die more quickly, and perhaps with a pleasant glow...

This essay brought back memories of seeing Mr. Parks' retrospective at the Corcoran in 1997. I didn't know about him or his work until then. I later read his autobiography and wrote a paper about his work for my African American Studies class in college. One of the amazing things is the diversity of his collection. there is his social justice photography here in American and elsewhere. However, he was also the first African American photographer to shoot fashion photography for Vogue and others. An amazing artist whose recent death has left a void.

Another hard-hitting combination, on target as usual. Dr. Krugman is right to remind us that household de-leveraging and the surplus of savings over investment are the main reasons our economy is sub-par. Just how big are these issues?

Regarding deleveraging: From 2000-2008, households added $260 billion per quarter to their debt level, about 1.9% GDP. Since the crisis, we've been paying it down about $50 billion per quarter, about 0.4% GDP. This is a 2.3% GDP swing due to deleveraging, a huge drag on the economy. This means that most of our economic growth during the Bush years was due to private borrowing and spending. The government has to step in and provide that demand.

Further, the gap between savings and investment remains about $800 billion, when these numbers used to move in tandem. Dr. Krugman graphed this in his blog post called "The Problem" some time ago. Housing investment is still $400 billion below peak. If companies won't spend it, we tax it away from them. Corporate taxes are about 1.7% GDP, versus 2.7% GDP in 2007 and 2.5% GDP in the OECD.

Economies are built one job at a time. We created about 20 million jobs each decade from 1970-2000, but only about 4 million jobs since then. There are two big debates going on right now, the "Austerity vs. Stimulus" debate (which is about budget deficits and debt) and the "Structural vs. Cyclical" debate (which is about jobs). We should be having a lot more of the latter and a lot less of the former.
Awareness! As painful as it might be is the beginning to possible solutions... Awfully painful but word remembering as a cause.

We all should be weeping.
This entire world is in dire need of change.
A change of hearts and a change of mindsets.
Education will be the key to that kingdom of better understanding.
And that is what Mr. Aristregi's efforts are: education.
Thank you Mr. Aristregi and thank you NYT.
This is why I too subscribe, when I get the privilege of an article like this and the photos.

I found Mr. Brooks wonderment over Kosher food little more than a condescending cheap shot.

I also can't wait to restock on Passover goodies too like macaroons, Elite chocolates,egg matzo, and those imported matzos from Israel.

The diet starts again after Passover.

When you live in the NY metro area as is likley the case in the Los Angeles area, one cannot miss the cultural contributions and the charm of many things Jewish. We are talking about apartments, delis, cars, businesses, shows, art, shops, and the recently passed and loved by everyone Mayor Koch who once said "mayor trumps rabbi."

But it is true, ultra orthodox anything has its share of consequences. You look at these sequestered communities and the folks in them who never get to eat a burrito or a McDonalds breakfast muffin. How about surf boarding, fly fishing, sky diving and skiing?

Whenever I come across a family that is into home schooling when there are great public and private schools around the yellow lights start blinking.

It's funny (in a nice way) to read about Mr. Brooks' wonderment over Kosher food. It's something I've known all my life. Manischevitz used to be it. That was a long time ago. While we don't have a Pomegranate here in the Los Angeles area, we do have Jewish markets that have served the community for many years. The big supermarket chains all carry a reasonable amount of products aimed at the Jewish population. I am looking forward to replenishing my stash of Alprose Parve Kosher for Passover chocolate bars. I get those at our local Pavilions store.

Jews have survived all these centuries in the diaspora because they've maintained their identity and tradition. The pre-cut napkins and gourmet Glatt-Kosher and gluten-free cheeses are beside the point.

I just love this paragraph, Professor Krugman:

"So what the bad predictions tell us is that we are, in effect, dealing with priests who demand human sacrifices to appease their angry gods — but who actually have no insight whatsoever into what those gods actually want, and are simply projecting their own preferences onto the alleged mind of the market."

I would just add one thing: not only are they projecting their preferences, they're projecting their interests.

The high priests you speak of are members of (or stooges working for) a rentier class who simply don't relate to the struggles of people who work for a living everyday. They have assets, and they want them protected. They don't really subscribe to free market ideology. If they did, they would have to concede that the law of supply and demand is real and that it works. And they would have to recognize that we've been in an economy where demand is anemic.

I just wonder when it's ever going to change.

Income inequality is one of the big imbalances in the economy we've got right now. Dr. Krugman covered the savings surplus and deleveraging in this Op Ed. High unemployment and trade deficit are the others.

These require some structural reforms to address, in addition to cyclical stimulus in the interim while we make the adjustments. Some examples of solutions already in motion:

Income inequality: Obama has raised taxes on the top 1% and is pitching an increase in the minimum wage.

Savings surplus: We won't get much help here until housing investment rebounds; it is presently about $400 billion below. We'll probably just have to wait this one out, covering the hole with deficit spending in the interim.

Deleveraging: If the Fed can generate some wage-driven inflation, it would help households enormously in paying down their fixed mortgages. If the Fed rolled the dice and printed say $3 trillion and credited homeowner mortgages (a gigantic household bailout) this would make an enormous difference.

Unemployment and trade deficit: We are fools to think we can allow our corporations to source in low wage countries and think it won't kill our jobs engine. We simply have to tax companies for the wage differential so they bring the jobs home.

Blaming the President for the trend to greater inequality means you haven't been paying attention. The process began under Reagan with cuts to top tax rates and the dismantling of the regulatory structures that had been developed over the preceding half century. You only need to look at one of Emmanuel Saez's well-known graphs to see this:

http://www.economist.com/blogs/freeexchange/2012/03/income-inequality

Let's put the blame where it belongs, shall we?

Obama and Krugman threw senior citizens, the middle class, and the under class under the bus to enrich themselves and the ultra-rich. There is one and only one segment that has actually witnessed economic enrichment under Obama and that has been the top 1%. Krugman knows this but he is too busy swimming in money to care about all of those who have been punished the most and have been forced to finance his largess for the ultra rich - the working class. Have a good game of golf with Obama and your buddies Krugman, and thanks for nothing for selling out the working people of this country and the working people all over the world. At least the stock market is going up, heh?

There is no such thing as a "Market God." It is not some independent entity with a will of its own. It is a marketplace for buying and selling pieces of companies. The price of those pieces is called equity in the company that sold the stock originally. The value of these pieces of equity is determined by those who are willing to pay the asking price, or can bargain for it.

If I think a share of GE is worth $20 that is the price I will pay. If you want $30 for it, you will have to find some other buyer. People did not lose their savings, jobs and mental health from the "perverse antics of the Market God." They lost because many people were willing to overlook the true value of something they never should have invested in. They had the get rich quick bug, and it is not the first time. The "Market" is passive, it has no soul, it does nothing, it is just a name for a place where people go to make deals, not much different than your local flea market.

No one forces you to buy or sell there, but it you are ignorant, or greedy, or both,you will lose. The "Market" does however give some prediction of the direction the economy will take in the future, usually in a year to 18 months.

There is more to the market than just equities, there is also a corporate bond market. You buy a corporate bond, in effect, you have lent money to the company and are a senior debt holder. When sock are traded, the company does not get anything for them unless it is a new issue.
So as the economy contracts and expands these days, the rich use it to get richer and make the poor poorer.

In addition to high unemployment, the offshoring of jobs, and low bond yields, the market has surged for another important reason. After the crash that triggered the Great Recession, there was a big shakeout as underexperienced and overleveraged investors got out of the market. Their stakes were purchased by wealthier investors who can weather a storm and won't skittishly pull their money out in a downturn. This decreased volatility and boosted confidence. It also increased the concentration of wealth in the hands of the very few.

I have a degree at the number one university in the current UK Times World University Rankings. I put it that way because most people have never heard of Caltech (California Institute of Technology), in spite of the fact that it has twice the percentage of Nobel Laureate alumni than Harvard.

A few years ago I was living in Manhattan and applied for an IT position at the NY Times. My phone interview was from a man with a thick south Asian accent who proceeded to ask technical questions with impossibly precise answers, such as the list of command line options for a particular source code control system. I asked if I could be given a few seconds to look up the answer on my own development system (which was at hand), but was told that the answer had to come from my head because "anybody could look it up".

That style of questioning continued until the interviewer told me I wasn't qualified for the position. I suppose that must have been true, because it took me a while to realize that the "interview" was merely a means to demonstrate a formal "search" before hiring an H1-B import.

After may similar outcomes, I left NYC and returned to Australia (I'm a dual US/Australian national), where labor laws make such experiences much less common, though not unheard of.

I think this comment will be a good test of the NY Times' journalistic integrity. Let's see if they publish a bad interview experience from their own house.

I have 30 years experience and my last job was well under 6 figures 12 years ago. 4 months ago I took a crappy retail job where my monthly take home (after medical deductions) was less than unemployment: $1200. Over half my pay goes to rent and if I wasn't getting food stamps I'd be eating part-time. Absurd.
I've tried this but can't seem to get the business,run the business and do the business single-handed.

Reading  the comments I'm appalled by all the hoops people are being put through these days. The common thread is the rise of HR., There, also seems to be, to me, in all the comments the foundation for a hit movie. Call it 'Screwed'. Now one of you smarty pants get to work on a screenplay.

I am very disconcerted with your posting because one, I think the experience you touch upon is horrific and an abomination to the HR industry, and two, because I myself am a HR professional. I hate to say it, but you are right, many of my colleagues in this industry relish their role as gate-keepers with little understanding of what actually is needed to succeed in the open position. However, there are also many who are strategic advisors and can find the right opportunity for you.

My suggestion for you is that the best way to find a position is to contact hiring managers directly via your own networks. Or utilize resources such as LinkedIn.com to make new contacts.

Wish you the best of luck in your job search!

To the writer of this article - I disagree with your assessment of why employers are holding back in hiring. In my opinion, less is more.  Computers, the internet  and technology allow one person to do more than one job at a time - so many companies now hold off on new hires because the current employees can pick up the slack! Many times the position is NEVER filled, or is re-categorized from (for example) management to clerical. The new employee is paid much less than the predicessor. Then there is the issue of co-workers and the 'team' mentality.  We all spend so much of our lives at work that it does matter who you work with and what the environment is like.  Can you manage to get along and work well together, at least most of the time?  I think the future will see more freelance and independent workers contracting their efforts for a certain price and specific time.

Timothy Egan, thank you very much for a timely and excellent article. Since the Times has reorganized and eliminated its climate desk, as well as having Mr. Nocera traduce real authority, it's excellent to see the forces of reality being noticed here.

I don't agree about giving up. We must do everything in our power to switch to and establish clean energy sources, including mounting a major effort to study and develop better sources, storage, and transmission are important. Ultimately, the idea that we can somehow adapt while we continue to abrade our planet simply does not work.

In addition, we must stop letting powerful corporations and politicians persecute hardworking scientists, and fund not far-out space programs but our more local weather and other observational satellites that help us know and understand our own planetary dynamics.

There is good reason for the intermingling at an annual conference. Prosecutors are not regulating criminal defense attorneys. Rather, the private attorneys represent defendants (or potential defendants) and both sets of attorneys are officers of the court engaged in a single process - that of legally charging defendants with criminal violations - in which the sets of attorneys pay complementary roles. That members of a profession who have different but intersecting roles exchange professional views and knowledge and have personal connections in itself is not improper in the least.

The real question is whether the vigor of prosecutions in business cases is weakened by higher-ups in the federal gov't due to regulatory capture of the political system by large corporate entities combined with restraints arising from the career ambitions of prosecutors who hope to represent such clients when they move to private firms. To me, this is an evident part of the story of the last decade but was hard to discern because it is a story of what has not happened (a dearth of prosecutions). That this has finally become evident is exemplified by individuals such as Alan Binder (while doing media promoting his book) remarking on the lack of Wall St. prosecutions. The DOJ response now seems to be a determination of obtain guilty pleas from subsidiaries of corporations - not a deep change in the dynamic but essentially symbolic convictions to which they can point to deflect criticism.

With all the excuses and the failure to ever -- ever, ever, ever, ever -- go after any individual within these institutions for permitting illegal activity, it seems almost conclusive that the Obama administration is melding itself within a Wall Street mindset and does not care one whit about genuine enforcement. It's a disgrace. The question is, with no campaign money needed any longer, why? Does it have something to do with post-presidency opportunities and positioning? It's a puzzle.

How in the world would a criminal action against HBSC for repeated money laundering of hundreds of millions of dollars in drug money and violating U.S. economic sanctions against a number or regimes bring down the world financial system or have a negative effect on the world economy? Who here thinks Eric Holder could give a coherent statement defending that official excuse for not pursuing blatant lawlessness? Even if Holder is afraid to take on an institution likely to be one of his future clients, how in creation would a criminal action against an individual law-breaker cause economic or financial system turmoil?

You appear to have bought fake skeptic PR wholesale and spout multiple talking points. Take a broader look at all the news, not just the material that fits your preconceptions. You will find the facts contradict the prepackaged points which we are not allowed to call denial, since political correctness only works one way. Our planet doesn't care about your politics, and it does not have tunnel vision.

Your example about Australia is particularly wrongheaded. Yes, there are droughts and floods, but the sum has been disastrous for them in all-too-recent history (this year, in fact).

I don't think it's the water temperature that is the problem - it's the acidity of the ocean.

The ozone layer is returning based on actions man has taken to reduce the use of chemicals that damage it,

The artic ice may be growing since it is winter but the annual trend is obvious to anyone, even the most addled.

Record snowfalls in the Alps? Europe gets enough water from rain. Places like California do depend on melting dispersed over the summer to provide rain; I've never heard of a problem in the Alps.

You don't seem to have a good grasp of reality. But you talk down to us humans as if you are omniscient. You are not. You are in error.

John from Thailand: You use a number of incorrect conclusions:
1) 'warming' is just one of the effects of global 'Climate Change' that includes all kind of extreme weathers.
2)" reefs ... are in water 2 degrees hotter and they thrive"
It is not just temperature (or different corals) but acidification that affect reefs.
3)" The ice sheets have begun growing again in the arctic..."
Yes, it is winter now. The year-round data shows a different trend
4) "record snow falls in the alps means no lack of water down below"
Most rivers are fed by spring melt from glaciers & Ice. Glaciers are shrinking + isolated local snowfalls will not be enough to make up for the general warming + lack of snow. On the latter, ask ski tourism.
5)" I am sure to be bombarded by the greens out there". The data does not come from 'greens' but from rock-hard science.

The world has not warmed for the past 16 years causing many scientists to revisit their models that said really bad things would happen. In Australia for example after a near record breaking drought  the experts said it would never again rain enough to fill the dams. The guru's frightened state governments with all their dire predictions into building huge desalination plants costing billions. Anyone watching international news would know the very cities that have now mothballed these billion dollar anti drought measures have suffered severe flooding and near record rains.  The greens claim a 2 degree rise in temperature will kill off large sections of the Great Barrier Reef. The fact is All the reefs around New Guinea are in water 2 degrees hotter and they thrive. The ozone layer is shrinking to almost nothing...The ice sheets have begun growing again in the arctic....record snow falls in the alps means no lack of water down below as predicted and many other peer reviewed papers are available to show it has all happened before and there is nothing man can do to change it. I am sure to be bombarded by the greens out there calling me out of touch or crazy, part of a oil company or whatever. I have been around for over 70 years and have seen it all before.

The "interest-rate story" is mysteriously lacking in a description of the Federal Reserve's role in the historically low interest rates with which the federal government can borrow. Undoubtedly, Paul is up-to-date on the Fed's vastly expanded balance sheet and great challenges it faces in the second half of the decade, and he truly believes in its actions to help stimulate the economy through low interest rates and government lending--and therefore government spending, which is laudable, but he routinely fails to elaborate on why interest rates are so low and the risks the Fed--and by extension the United States--is taking to keep them so low for so long.

Given the stock market's recent rally following the sequester, Paul needs to provide his readers with substantially better reasoning to further "ramp up spending to support the economy" to use his words. As a young person faced with supporting a spendthrift yet needy future elderly class and as a citizen of a country whose budget is never projected to balance, I fear goosing up the federal balance sheet now (read: liabilities) in pursuit of short-term solutions, given our long-term problems are so grave.

You have the right idea. I have been studying the "Market" for 50 years now. the problem has always been, when it gets hot, a bunch of amateurs jump in expecting to get rich quick. These are the ones the buy high and sell low, and then complain about losing money.

They do not know how to read the financials, understand the percentages such as P/E, read cash flow and long term debt, they just seem to think by buying into some fund they are going to get rich.

The doomsayers have been around every since the NYSE opened and they have been wrong all those years. Even when some such as National City Bank of New York City was able to bring it to a low point, investment in good stable well managed companies has paid off.

I limit my holdings to companies that pay good dividends, and have good balance sheets. Fortunately I have managed to get enough ahead that I can take some risk occasionally, and have done pretty well with them.

There are a couple of rules of investing. You do not spend your capital, and you do not lose until you sell. For instance, if you had paid in the $50s for GE around 2004, then sold it for $10 in 2008, you lost. If you kept it you would be getting dividends and it is back up to $23 and will go higher.

I was told a long time ago, a very long time, that no one can successfully time the market. Invest or not that is the only decision. I can't complain. I am a working stiff who is now quite comfortable as a result of dollar cost averaging and just staying the course.

Even a noble prize isn't a ticket to success in the market. Cheating no doubt is, but beyond that the best you can do is select a strategy based on the efficient frontier, dollar cost average and maintain a steady course.

Every time the doomsayers pontificate just ignore them and move on. You'll be OK.
